quest_title: The abscissa of the points of the curve \(y=x^{3} \) in the interval [--2, 2], where the slope of the tangents can be obtained by mean value theorem for the interval [-2, 2], are
explanation_txt:
Given that equation of curve \(y=x^{3} =f(x)\)

So \(f(2) =8\) and \(f(-2)=-8\)

Now \(f'(x)=3x^{2} \Rightarrow f'(x)=\cfrac{f(2)-f(-2)}{2-(-2)} \)

\[ \Rightarrow \cfrac{8-(-8)}{4} =3x^{2} ;\]

\[{\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} x=\pm \cfrac{2}{\sqrt{3} } .\]

quest_title: Two ships A and B are 4km apart in which ship A is due west of ship B. Ship A move with 8 km/hr toward east and B move with 6 km/hr toward south then closest distance between two ship will be
explanation_txt:
Closest distance is the perpendicular distance of relative velocity

\(\begin{array}{l}{\quad \tan \alpha=\cfrac{v_{\mathrm{B}}}{v_{\mathrm{A}}}=\cfrac{6}{8}} \\ {\text { or, } \alpha=\tan ^{-1}\left(\cfrac{3}{4}\right)=36.86^{\circ}} \\ {\text { Again, } \sin \alpha=\cfrac{\mathrm{BP}}{\mathrm{AB}}} \\ {\text { or, } \mathrm{BP}=\mathrm{AB} \sin \alpha=4 \sin 36.86^{\circ}=2.4 \mathrm{km}}\end{array}\)
question_plain_title: Two ships A and B are 4km apart in which ship A is due west of ship B. Ship A move with 8 km/hr toward east and B move with 6 km/hr toward south then closest distance between two ship will be
explanation_plain_text: Closest distance is the perpendicular distance of relative velocity

quest_title: The horizontal force \(\text{P}\) required to move the block up the plane of inclination \(\text{\(\theta\) }\) as in figure is
explanation_txt:
\(P \cos \theta-W \sin \theta=\mu(P \sin \theta+W \cos \theta)\)

\(P \cos \theta-\mu P \sin \theta=\mu W \cos \theta+W \sin \theta\)

\(\therefore P=\cfrac{W(\mu \cos \theta+\sin \theta)}{\cos \theta-\mu \sin \theta}\)

explanation_txt:

\(\Rightarrow \cfrac { Q } { t } \propto \cfrac { K } { \rho c }\)

(K = thermal conductivity, \(\rho\) = density, c = specific heat)

quest_title: Under which of the following conditions will a convex mirror of focal length f produce an image that is erect, diminished and virtual
explanation_txt: Image formed by convex mirror is always. Erect diminished and virtual.
question_plain_title: Under which of the following conditions will a convex mirror of focal length f produce an image that is erect, diminished and virtual

quest_title: The true statement is
ans1_txt: The order of colours in the primary and the secondary rainbows is the same.
ans2_txt: The intensity of colours in the primary and the secondary rainbows is the same.
ans3_txt: The intensity of light in the primary rainbow is greater and the order of colours is the same than the secondary rainbow.
ans4_txt: The intensity of light for different colours in primary rainbow is greater and the order of colours is reverse than the secondary rainbow.
explanation_txt:
By Cmglee

In primary rainbow, there is single total internal reflection of light inside rain drops whereas in secondary rainbow, there is double internal refelction of light inside raindrops. More light escapes through two reflections compared to one. Therefore, secondary rainbow is fainter compared to primary rainbow. Further secondary rainbow faces two reflections causing the order of dispersion in reverse to the primary rainbow as shown in the figure.
question_plain_title: The true statement is
explanation_plain_text:
By Cmglee

In primary rainbow, there is single total internal reflection of light inside rain drops whereas in secondary rainbow, there is double internal refelction of light inside raindrops. More light escapes through two reflections compared to one. Therefore, secondary rainbow is fainter compared to primary rainbow. Further secondary rainbow faces two reflections causing the order of dispersion in reverse to the primary rainbow as shown in the figure.
ans1_plain_text: The order of colours in the primary and the secondary rainbows is the same.
ans2_plain_text: The intensity of colours in the primary and the secondary rainbows is the same.
ans3_plain_text: The intensity of light in the primary rainbow is greater and the order of colours is the same than the secondary rainbow.
ans4_plain_text: The intensity of light for different colours in primary rainbow is greater and the order of colours is reverse than the secondary rainbow.

quest_title: Two lenses are placed in contact with each other and the focal length of combination is 80 \(\textit{cm}\). If the focal length of one is 20 \(\textit{cm}\), then the power of the other will be
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{1}{F} =\cfrac{1}{f_{1} } +\cfrac{1}{f_{2} } \)\(\Rightarrow \cfrac{1}{80} =\cfrac{1}{20} +\cfrac{1}{f_{2} } \) \(\Rightarrow f_{2} =-\cfrac{80}{3} cm=0.266 m\)

\(\therefore\)Power of second lens \(P_{2} =\cfrac{1}{f_{2} } =\cfrac{1}{-0.266} =-3.75\; D\)
question_plain_title: Two lenses are placed in contact with each other and the focal length of combination is 80 . If the focal length of one is 20 , then the power of the other will be
explanation_plain_text: Power of second lens

quest_title: A far sighted person use a convex lens of power +2D to read a book at a distance of 25cm. The distance to which book should be placed without use of spectacles is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{P}=+2 \mathrm{D}\)

\(\mathrm{f}=1 / \mathrm{P}=1 / 2 \times 100 \mathrm{cm}=50 \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\mathrm{u}=25 \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\mathrm{v}=\cfrac{\mathrm{fu}}{\mathrm{u}-\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{50 \times 25}{25-50}=-50 \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\therefore\) near point \(=50 \mathrm{cm}\)
question_plain_title: A far sighted person use a convex lens of power +2D to read a book at a distance of 25cm. The distance to which book should be placed without use of spectacles is
explanation_plain_text: near point

quest_title: If the ratio of intensities of two waves is 1 : 25, then the ratio of their amplitudes will be
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac { I _ { 1 } } { I _ { 2 } } = \cfrac { 1 } { 25 }\)

Intensity of a wave is directly proportional to square of its amplitude.

\(I\propto A^{2}\)

\( \Rightarrow \cfrac{I_{1}}{I_{2}}=\cfrac { A _ { 1 } ^ { 2 } } { A _ { 2 } ^ { 2 } } = \cfrac { 1 } { 25 }\)

\(\Rightarrow \cfrac { A _ { 1 } } { A _ { 2 } } = \cfrac { 1 } { 5 }\)
question_plain_title: If the ratio of intensities of two waves is 1 : 25, then the ratio of their amplitudes will be
explanation_plain_text: Intensity of a wave is directly proportional to square of its amplitude.

quest_title: In the far field diffraction pattern of a single slit under polychromatic illumination, the first minimum with the wavelength \(\lambda_{1}\) is found to be coincident with the third maximum at \(\lambda_{2}\). So
explanation_txt:
Position of first minima due to diffraction of light of wavelength \(\lambda_{1}\)= position of third maxima due to diffraction of light of wavelength \(\lambda_{2}\)

i.e. \(\cfrac { 1 \times \lambda _ { 1 } D } { d } = \cfrac { ( 2 \times 3 + 1 ) } { 2 } \cfrac { \lambda _ { 2 } D } { d }\)

\(\Rightarrow \lambda _ { 1 } = 3.5 \lambda _ { 2 }\)

quest_title: An observer moves towards a stationary source of sound of frequency \(\textit{n}\). The apparent frequency heard by him is 2\(\textit{n}\). If the velocity of sound in air is 332 m/sec, then the velocity of the observer is
explanation_txt:
When observer moves toward the source, apparant frequency is given as

\(n'=n\, \left(\cfrac{v+v_{O} }{v} \right)\Rightarrow 2n=n\, \left(\cfrac{v+v_{0} }{v} \right)\Rightarrow \cfrac{v+v_{0} }{v} =2\) \(\Rightarrow \)\(v_{O} =v=332\)\(\textit{m/sec}\)
question_plain_title: An observer moves towards a stationary source of sound of frequency . The apparent frequency heard by him is 2. If the velocity of sound in air is 332 m/sec, then the velocity of the observer is
explanation_plain_text: When observer moves toward the source, apparant frequency is given as

ans2_plain_text: 664 /

ans4_plain_text: 1328 /

quest_title: The wavelength of k line of x-ray produced in x-ray tube is 0.76\(\mathring{A}\) then atomic no. of material of tube will be
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{1}{\lambda}=(Z-1)^{2} R\left(\cfrac{1}{1^{2}}-\cfrac{1}{2^{2}}\right)\)
Or, \((Z-1)^{2}=\cfrac{1}{\lambda R} \cfrac{4}{3}\)
Or, \(Z-1=\sqrt{\cfrac{1}{0.76 \times 10^{-10} \times 1.097 \times 10^{7}} \times \cfrac{4}{3}}\)
\(\qquad\qquad=40\)
Or, \(Z=41\)

quest_title: If 1 gm radium emits 3.7\(\times\)10\({}^{10}\) particle/ s (c)Find the mean life period of radium. (At. wt.\(\rightarrow\) 226, N = 6.025\(\times\)10\({}^{23}\)gm/mole)
explanation_txt:
\(226 \mathrm{g}\) has \(6.025 \times 10^{23}\) atoms
\(1 \mathrm{g}=\cfrac{6.025 \times 10^{23}}{226}=2.66 \times 10^{21}\) atoms
Here,
\(\mathrm{A}=\lambda \mathrm{N}\)
or, \(\lambda=\cfrac{3.7 \times 10^{10}}{2.66 \times 10^{21}}=1.39 \times 10^{-11} / \mathrm{s}\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{T}=\cfrac{1}{\lambda}=7.1 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{s}=2275 \mathrm{yrs}\)

ans3_txt: Solubility product of \(\textit{AgI }\) is less than that of \(\textit{NaI}\)

\(NaI\) \(\mathrm{\rightleftharpoons}\) \(Na^{+} +\, \, \, \, I^{-} \)

quest_title: Which of the following is incorrect statement ?
ans1_txt: Permanent hardness is due to dissolved chlorides and sulphates of calcium and magnesium
ans2_txt: It can be removed by mere boiling of water
ans3_txt: It is also known as non-alkaline hardness
ans4_txt: The difference between the total hardness and the alkaline hardness gives the non-alkaline hardness
explanation_txt:
Permanent hardness is not removed on boiling.

Varoius methods are adopted for the removal of permanent hardness like zeolites, lime-soda process etc.

quest_title: 5 lumen/watt is the luminous efficiency of a lamp and its luminous intensity is 35 candela. The power of the lamp is
explanation_txt:
Efficiency of light source \(\eta =\cfrac{\phi }{p} \) ..... (i) and \(L=\cfrac{\phi }{4\pi } \) ..... (ii)

From equation (i) and (ii),

\(P=\cfrac{4\pi L}{\eta } =\cfrac{4\pi \times 35}{5} \approx 88\, W. \)

quest_title: What is O.N. of Cl in \(\text{CaOCl\(_{2}\)}\)
explanation_txt:
Two \(Cl\) atom shows +1 and -1 oxidation state.

One Cl atom is bonded to Ca which has -1 oxidation state whereas Cl atom bonded to O has oxidation state +1.

\[\overset{+2}Ca(\overset{-2}O\,\overset{+1}Cl)\overset{-1}Cl\]

quest_title: A capacitor has capacitance \({C}\) in air. The either half part of the plate is filled with a dielectric of constant \({K}\). The new capacitance will be
explanation_txt:
Now,
\(C_{1}=\cfrac{K \varepsilon_0 \cfrac{A}{2}}{d}=\cfrac{K}{2} \cfrac{\varepsilon_0 A}{d}=\cfrac{K}{2} C\)
\(C_{2}=\cfrac{\varepsilon_0 \cfrac{A}{2}}{d}=\cfrac{1}{2} \cfrac{\varepsilon_0 A}{d}=\cfrac{1}{2} C\)
\(C_1\) and \(C_2\) are in parallel, hence
\(C^{\prime}=C_{1}+C_{2}=\cfrac{K}{2} C+\cfrac{1}{2} C\)
\(C^{\prime}=\left(\cfrac{K+1}{2}\right) C\)

quest_title: A magnetic field of 2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-2}\) Tesla acts at right angles to a coil of area 100 cm\({}^{2}\) with 50 turns. The average e.m.f. induced in the coil is 0.1 V when it is removed from the field in time `\(\text{t}\)'. The value of `\(\text{t}\)' is
explanation_txt:
\(E=-\cfrac{d \phi}{d t}=-n A \cfrac{d \phi}{d t} \)
\(\Rightarrow 0.1=\cfrac{50 \times\left(100 \times 10^{-4}\right) \times\left(2 \times 10^{-2}\right)}{t} \)
\(\therefore t=0.1 \text { second } \)

quest_title: Iron rusts in the presence of
explanation_txt:
Rusting of iron is an electrochemical process that begins with the transfer of electrons from iron to oxygen. Diatomic oxyden itself is stable, so to get reduced presence of water is necessary.

The key reaction is reduction of oxygen

\(\mathrm{O}_{2}+4 \mathrm{e}^{-}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightarrow 4 \mathrm{OH}^{-}\)

and the series of reactions are as follows

Oxidation of iron

\(\mathrm{Fe} \rightarrow \mathrm{Fe}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{e}^{-}\)

Overall Redox reaction

\(4 \mathrm{Fe}^{2+}+\mathrm{O}_{2} \rightarrow 4 \mathrm{Fe}^{3+}+2 \mathrm{O}^{2-}\)

Acid-Base Reactions

\(\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Fe}(\mathrm{OH})_{2}+2 \mathrm{H}^{+}\)

\(\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}+3 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Fe}(\mathrm{OH})_{3}+3 \mathrm{H}^{+}\)

Dehydration equilibrium

\(\mathrm{Fe}(\mathrm{OH})_{2} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{FeO}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\)

\(\mathrm{Fe}(\mathrm{OH})_{3} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{FeO}(\mathrm{OH})+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\)

\(2 \mathrm{FeO}(\mathrm{OH}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Fe}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}.\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\)
question_plain_title: Iron rusts in the presence of
explanation_plain_text:
Rusting of iron is an electrochemical process that begins with the transfer of electrons from iron to oxygen. Diatomic oxyden itself is stable, so to get reduced presence of water is necessary.

The key reaction is reduction of oxygen

and the series of reactions are as follows

Oxidation of iron

Overall Redox reaction

Acid-Base Reactions

Dehydration equilibrium
ans2_plain_text: and moisture
ans4_plain_text: and Nitrogen

quest_title: The point on the parabola \(y ^ { 2 } = 8 x\) at which the normal is inclined at 60o to the x-axis has the co-ordinates :
explanation_txt:
Normal at (h,k) to the parabola \(y ^ { 2 } = 8 x\) is \(y - k = - \cfrac { k } { 4 } ( x - h )\)

Gradient \(= \tan 60 ^ { \circ } = \sqrt { 3 } = - \cfrac { k } { 4 } \Rightarrow k = - 4 \sqrt { 3 }\) and \(h=6\)

Hence required point is \(( 6 , - 4 \sqrt { 3 } )\).

quest_title: If P and Q be the middle points of the sides BC and CD of the parallelogram ABCD, then \(\overrightarrow{AP} +\overrightarrow{AQ} =\)
explanation_txt:
\(\overrightarrow{AP} \, =\overrightarrow{AB} +\overrightarrow{BP} =\overrightarrow{AB} +\cfrac{1}{2} \overrightarrow{BC} =\overrightarrow{AB} +\cfrac{1}{2} \overrightarrow{AD} \) \({\dots}..(i)\)

\(\overrightarrow{AQ} =\overrightarrow{AD} +\overrightarrow{DQ} =\overrightarrow{AD} +\cfrac{1}{2} \overrightarrow{DC} =\overrightarrow{AD} +\cfrac{1}{2} \overrightarrow{AB} \) \(\dots..(ii) \)

By (i) and (ii), we get,

\[\overrightarrow{AP} +\overrightarrow{AQ} =\cfrac{3}{2} (\overrightarrow{AB} +\overrightarrow{AD} )=\cfrac{3}{2} (\overrightarrow{AB} +\overrightarrow{BC} )=\cfrac{3}{2} \overrightarrow{AC} .\]

explanation_plain_text: By (i) and (ii), we get,

quest_title: A body of 10 kg is acted by a force of 129.4 N if g = 9.8m/s2 . The acceleration of the block is 10m/s2 . What is the coefficient of kinetic friction?
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { \text { Net force on the body } = \text { Applied force - Friction } } \\ { m a = F - \mu _ { k } m g \Rightarrow \mu _ { k } = \cfrac { F - m a } { m g } = \cfrac { 129.4 - 10 \times 10 } { 10 \times 9.8 } = 0.3 } \end{array}\)

quest_title: A body of mass M slides down an inclined plane and reaches to the bottom with a velocity v. If same mass were in the form of ring which rolls down this plane, the velocity of ring at bottom of plane is
explanation_txt:
Now \(v^{2}=2 a s=2 g \sin \theta \cdot s \) .......(i)
For ring,
\(I=M R^{2}=M K^{2}\)
\(\therefore K=1\)

\(\mathrm{a}^{\prime}=\cfrac{\mathrm{g} \sin \theta}{1+\cfrac{\mathrm{k}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}^{2}}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{g} \sin \theta}{2}\)
\(\mathrm{v}^{\prime 2}=2 \mathrm{a}^{\prime} \mathrm{s}=\cfrac{2 g \sin \theta s}{2}=\cfrac{v^{2}}{2}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{v}^{\prime}=\cfrac{v}{\sqrt{2}}\)

quest_title: A sphere of copper having an internal cavity weights 200g in air and 176g in water. The density of copper is 8.8g/cc the volume of cavity is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array}{l}{\text { Loss in wt }=\text { upthrust }} \\ {\text { or, } 200-176=\mathrm{V} \sigma_{\mathrm{w}} \quad \therefore \mathrm{V}=24 \mathrm{cc}} \\ {\text { For metal }} \\ {\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{m}}=\cfrac{200}{8.8}=22.7 \mathrm{cc}} \\ {\therefore \text { volume of cavity }=\mathrm{V}-\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{m}}} \\ {=24-22.7=1.3 \mathrm{cc}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: The temperature at which reading of Fahrenheit scale become three times the reading on calcius scale is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{C}=\mathrm{x}} \\ {\mathrm{F}=3 \mathrm{x}} \\ {\cfrac{C}{100}=\cfrac{F-32}{180}} \\ {\Rightarrow \cfrac{C}{5}=\cfrac{F-32}{9}}\end{array}\)

\(\begin{aligned} \therefore 9 x &=15 x-160 \\ x &=\cfrac{160}{6} \\ &=\cfrac{80}{3}^{\circ} \mathrm{C} = 80 ^{\circ} \mathrm{F} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: Which of the following has maximum specific heat?
explanation_txt:
Water has maximum specific heat = 4200 J/kg.

Specific heat of alchohol = 2460 J/kg

Specific heat of glycerine = 2430 J/kg

Specific heat of oil = 1670 J/kg

quest_title: Molecules of a gas behave like
explanation_txt:
Modeling of gas molecules in ideal gas equation is done considering the following points:-

  • All molecular collisions are elastic in nature i.e. gas molecules are elastic.
  • Gas molecules are the smallest entity of a gas and are rigid.

quest_title: A light has amplitude A and angle between analyzer and polarizer is 60°. Light is reflected by analyzer has amplitude
explanation_txt:
Intensity of light \(I \propto A^{2}\) where \(A\) is amplitude of light.

From Malus's law,

\(I = I _ { 0 } \cos ^ { 2 } \theta \text { and } A ^ { 2 } = A _ { 0 } ^ { 2 } \cos ^ { 2 } \theta \Rightarrow A = A _ { 0 } \cos \theta\)

\(\therefore\) The amplitude will be \(A \cos 60 ^ { \circ } = A / 2\)

quest_title: A radioactive source had decayed to 1/128\({}^{th}\) of its initial activity after 49 days. What is its half-life?
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{N}{N_{o}}=\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{t}{T_{1 / 2}}}\)
or, \(\cfrac{1}{128}=\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{t}{T_{1 / 2}}}\)
or, \(\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{7}=\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{t}{T_{1 / 2}}}\)
or, \(T_{1 / 2}=\cfrac{49}{7}=7\) days
